{"step_by_step_thinking": "The patient's symptoms include hyperextension at the metacarpophalangeal joint and flexion at the proximal interphalangeal joint of the 4th and 5th fingers. This is a classic description of ulnar claw, also known as claw hand or spinster's claw. According to Document 29, this deformity develops due to ulnar nerve damage causing paralysis of the lumbricals. Therefore, the injury is likely to the ulnar nerve.", "answer_choice": "A"}
